metadata.description:
The Illusions series delves into the enduring myth of the Vahine, a concept that has pervaded Western art since Paul Gauguin's 1891 journey to Tahiti. Drawing inspiration from Gauguin's tropical paintings, Illusions challenges the colonial perspective that depicted Polynesian women as attractive, desirable, and submissive, suggesting a mystical connection between their bodies, souls, and the land.

This striking collection transcends traditional notions of identity by scrutinizing society's understanding of the relationship between the physical body and the spirit. Through portrayals of Mahus and Rae Raes, Illusions aims to uncover the soul's true beauty, casting the models as mythical beings that dwell in the liminal space between reality and fantasy. Adorned with cultural and social ornaments, these figures seamlessly meld with nature in their quest to unearth their authentic selves.

An underlying sense of strangeness permeates the series, hinting at a discord between the body and spirit that mirrors disparities in expression, emotion, and perception. By delving into the hybridization of genders, Illusions offers fresh insights into the intricacies of identity that extend beyond mere physical appearance.
metadata.name: Under the Palms
